I am elated that my Joint Consolidation Loan Separation Act passed the House and is now heading to @POTUS to sign into law!

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text:
I'm heading to the floor now to vote YES for my Joint Consolidation Loan Separation Act.

I urge my colleagues to pass this life-changing bill and bring justice to borrowers stuck in punishing financial situations due to an abusive or uncommunicative partner.

Watch my speech‚§µÔ∏è https://t.co/ExpAhU1PaS

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: RT @RepHaleyStevens: Today, we debated the Joint Consolidation Loan Separation Act ‚Äì bipartisan legislation I am proud to co-lead in the Ho‚Ä¶

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: .@RepAlGreen said it best ‚Äî ‚Äúthe JCL bill is bipartisan, bicameral, and by God, we ought to pass it.‚Äù

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: .@RepGregMurphy: supporting the intent of the JCL bill means voting YES when it comes to the floor, period. The bill isn't partisan, and the vote shouldn't be either.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: The Joint Consolidation Loan Separation Act presents a rare opportunity for Congress to right a wrong, to correct an omission in its own legislative process. This bill offers fair and equitable relief to borrowers who have suffered great hardship.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: These borrowers have seen their wages garnished; credit scores ruined to the point where they cannot assist their own children in taking out federal student loans. The impact we‚Äôre seeing is generational.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: We have heard horror stories of people who have survived abusive relationships but continue to remain tied to their partners through this loan. Former partners have exerted financial abuse by refusing to co-pay with their exes.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: As a result, there are borrowers nationwide who remain financially liable for their absconded or abusive or uncommunicative spouse‚Äôs portion of their consolidated debt with no legal options for relief.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: Congress eliminated the program in 2006 but with one critical oversight ‚Äì Congress did not provide a means of severing the existing loans, even in the event of domestic abuse, economic abuse, or an unresponsive partner. There was, in other words, no grandfather clause.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: The Joint Consolidation Loan Separation Act is a simple bill in its intent, but significant in its impact on thousands of student loan borrowers who have waited for relief for far too long.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text:
Soon I will be speaking on the House floor about my bill, the Joint Consolidation Loan Separation Act. 

Watch live: https://t.co/qMc5OtCtJg https://t.co/YGeFR5h6Dy

name: Rep. David E. Price

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: Meanwhile, both the @HUDOIG and @USGAO have raised important questions about HUD‚Äôs internal capacity, staffing, and oversight of the CDBG-DR program.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: Of course, the CDBG-DR program is bigger than just PR, although PR does seem to have been singled out.  Many states, including NC, are implementing action plans or awaiting additional notices from HUD to use disaster funding that was appropriated last yr & in June of this yr.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text:
The other affected states had to wait 18 months, which was bad enough, but Puerto Rico is STILL waiting...

ICYMI: In PR‚ÄîNearly 3,000 people lost their lives, and tens of thousands of homes were damaged. I've been to PR and seen these challenges first hand.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: But that's not even the full story, rather than comply with the clear statutory deadline (included in bipartisan legislation signed by the President) to issue the Fed Reg notice, @HUDgov is still withholding the notice for PUERTO RICO.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: Low and middle-income families can‚Äôt wait 547 days to rebuild after a devastating storm.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text:
Issuing the Federal Register notice has taken longer in recent years.

After Sandy in 2012, it took 35 days.  After the 2017 hurricanes, it took 145 days.  And more recently it took 547 days, and even then the notice came only after Congress included a deadline by law.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: Without this notice, states (like NC) cannot submit action plans to @Hudgov, sign a grant agreement, and begin to use the $‚Äînecessary steps that take at least several months once the notice is issued.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text:
Unfortunately, Congress has never formally approved the CDBG-DR program. 

This means each time Congress gives $, @HUDgov must issue a notice in the Federal Register that outlines how the funds can be used.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text:
In 2017 alone, Congress set aside more than $35 billion across the federal government for people recovering from major hurricanes: Harvey, Irma, & Maria.

To put this into perspective, HUD‚Äôs entire budget in the last fiscal year was approximately $54 billion.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: Since 1993, Congress has provided more than $86 billion in funding for the CDBG-DR program.  As the severity and frequency of storms have increased, so has the need for funding. *climate change*

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: The grants primarily benefit low- and moderate-income people in the most impacted and distressed areas.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text: .@HUDgov‚Äôs Community Development Block Grant-Disaster Recovery program (CDBG-DR) is a flexible & vital tool for states & municipalities to recover from major disasters. Grantees use this funding to reconstruct damaged housing & repair public facilities such as community centers.

name: Rep. David E. Price
tweet_text:
THREAD: Today's @AppropsDems hearing highlights the Trump admin‚Äôs @HUDgov failure to follow the law & issue CDBG-DR mitigation notices for all grantees by the required deadline.

It‚Äôs a bit in the weeds, so let me explain...#ProfessorPrice
